ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was honestly my favorite this semester. I had a great time in discussion and it was great to have so many guest lecturers come into speak.
Non-traditional interventions for mental health in minority communities

I learned a lot about varying health, mostly psychological, conditions affecting Natives and the systemic factors that influence that. I also learned about the importance of the work being done to remedy these problems.

I learned about how cultural identity and modes of acculturation directly impact health for Indigenous people in the United States. I also developed writing skills through writing a 15 page final paper.

This course provided me an insightful introduction to how mental health practices are applied in Native American communities. I benefited from the small seminar with two professors that have professional experience. I have learned how to read psychology papers, look closely at data, and better techniques for research.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A strength of this course would be how awesome the professors are at facilitating discussions within the class. I also thought it was amazing that they were able to have so many guest lecturers in one semester.
I really appreciated the "leminar" (lecture/seminar) to explain core concepts but also having room for discussion. I just wish that we engaged a little bit more with the readings.

I think Drs. Beitel and Cutter did a great job in putting together a syllabus that managed to balance going in-depth with being digestible by someone who doesnt have prior knowledge about psychology. While several of the readings were a little long, they were engaging and not overwhelming. Overall, I feel like I got a solid introduction to the topic of Native health, specifically psychologically. This isnt a weakness, but I think it would be great to bring in more guest speakers in the future!

Because the class size was small, I would have appreciated more time allocated for discussion of the readings instead of the entire class time being used for lecture. However, the lectures were very informative, and I still appreciated the format of the class.

I think the course itself could be less of a lecture and more of a discussion seminar because of how few people were in it. We did discuss in class sometimes but I found myself bored because the class itself tended to be a lot of listening and reading.
I think it would be helpful to provide in-class essay writing for first and second-years especially.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having a seminar-discussion type learning mode as well as the smaller class size was great for allowing for discussions.

Drs. Cutter and Beitel were very understanding and accommodating. They tried not to overwhelm us and created a class environment that allowed us to learn while also being conscious of us as people first, checking in on us aside from just our ability to learn.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student. The perspectives offered here are not going to be found anywhere and anyone interested in Indigenous culture would greatly benefit from taking this course.

Yes absolutely! So much of the Clinical Psychology courses at Yale (and broadly) are focused on whiteness, so it was wonderful to have a course very decidedly NOT focused on that. I encourage any Psychologist of color to take it!

I would recommend this class! Id recommend it no matter what somebodys level of knowledge is, either in regard to Indigenous life or psychology. Both professors are thorough and really engage the class in a way that allows for valuable learning. This class was small, but even within that we had such variation in how familiar we were with these topics, but our professors were patient and made the information accessible.

Yes, I believe Indigenous student especially would find this course helpful even in their own personal lives. I learned a lot about mental health and treatments specific to Indigenous people and it is an important field of research.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It is important to note that the class does deal with heavy content, but it is important to understand how institutionalized mental health is practiced in non-White communities. This class has been eye-opening in reshaping my conceptions of societal norms that influence mental health norms. I appreciate that the class is cross-listed with ER&M and Psych as I feel that these fields are much more connected than individuals may think and that Psych often approaches situations without considering the historical context the way ER&M does.
